natural problem: Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (a, b) \<in> {(a::nat, b::nat). 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<and> (a * b) mod 5 = 0}. 1) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
 This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (a, b) \<in> {(a::nat, b::nat). 1 \<le> a \<and> a \<le> 6 \<and> 1 \<le> b \<and> b \<le> 6 \<and> (a * b) mod 5 = 0}. 1) / 36"
shows  "p = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A pair of fair six-sided dice is rolled, and the product of the numbers showing on the two dice is computed. What is the probability that the product is a multiple of 5? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (a, b) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (a * b) mod 5 = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
 This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (a, b) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (a * b) mod 5 = 0 then 1 else 0) / 36"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ that the product of two numbers randomly chosen from the sets $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$ is divisible by 5. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> probability a b = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a * b mod 5 = 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (a mod 5 = 0 \<or> b mod 5 = 0)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). probability a b) { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a * b mod 5 = 0 } = 11 / 36"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
 This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> probability a b = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "\<forall> a b. a * b mod 5 = 0 \<longleftrightarrow> (a mod 5 = 0 \<or> b mod 5 = 0)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> (a, b). probability a b) { (a, b) | a b. a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> a * b mod 5 = 0 } = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a fair dice game, each of the two dice has six faces numbered 1 to 6. The probability of each outcome (a, b) is 1/36, where a and b represent the numbers on the two dice. If a product of the numbers on the two dice, a * b, is divisible by 5, find the probability of this event occurring. The final answer is 11/36.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and B :: "nat set" and C :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "C = {(a, b) | a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> (a * b) mod 5 = 0}"
shows  "card C / (card A * card B) = 11 / 36"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
 This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes A :: "nat set" and B :: "nat set" and C :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h1 : "B = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}"
and h2 : "C = {(a, b) | a b. a \<in> A \<and> b \<in> B \<and> (a * b) mod 5 = 0}"
shows  "card C / (card A * card B) = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: There are two sets A and B, both containing the numbers {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Set C is formed by all the ordered pairs (a, b) where a is from set A and b is from set B, and the product of a and b is divisible by 5. Find the probability that a randomly chosen ordered pair from set C has a product divisible by 5. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (x * y) mod 5 = 0 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
a_4.formal solution:

 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum> (x, y) \<in> {1..6} \<times> {1..6}. if (x * y) mod 5 = 0 then 1 else 0) / (6 * 6)"
shows  "P = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ that the product of two numbers, each chosen randomly from the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$, is divisible by $5$. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>(i, j)\<in>{(i, j). i \<in> {1..6} \<and> j \<in> {1..6} \<and> (i * j) mod 5 = 0}. 1) / 36"
shows  "probability = 11 / 36"

a_5.informal problem: What is the probability of the product of two dice, each having six faces numbered from 1 to 6, being divisible by 5? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<longrightarrow> probability x y = 1 / 36"
and h1 : "(\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x * y) mod 5 = 0}. probability x y) = 11 / 36"
shows  "11 / 36 = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x * y) mod 5 = 0}. probability x y)"

 *)

shows  "11 / 36 = (\<Sum>(x, y) \<in> {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x * y) mod 5 = 0}. probability x y)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Two dice with 6 sides each, numbered 1 through 6, are rolled. What is the probability that the product of the numbers on the two dice is divisible by 5? The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = 11/36"
shows  "P = (card {(x, y). x \<in> {1..6} \<and> y \<in> {1..6} \<and> (x * y) mod 5 = 0}) / (card ({1..6} \<times> {1..6}))"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Two dice with faces numbered from 1 to 6 are rolled. Find the probability that the product of the numbers rolled is divisible by 5. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>n. if (n \<in> {1..6}) then 1/6 else 0)"
and h1 : "set_pmf (prob) = {1..6}"
and h2 : "indep_event (set_pmf (prob)) (set_pmf (prob))"
shows  "measure_pmf.prob (pair_pmf (prob) (prob)) {xy. (fst xy * snd xy) mod 5 = 0} = 11 / 36"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Two fair, 6-sided dice are thrown.  What is the probability that the product of the two numbers is a multiple of 5?  Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{11}{36}
 ### Proof
 Probability questions are sometimes answered by calculating the ways the event will NOT happen, then subtracting. In this problem the $1$, $2$, $3$, $4$ and $6$ faces are paired to create $5 \times 5 = 25$ number pairs whose product is NOT multiples of 5.
 This leaves $36 - 25 = 11$ ways to get a multiple of $5$, so the probability is $\boxed{\frac{11}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda>n. if (n \<in> {1..6}) then 1/6 else 0)"
and h1 : "set_pmf (prob) = {1..6}"
and h2 : "indep_event (set_pmf (prob)) (set_pmf (prob))"
shows  "measure_pmf.prob (pair_pmf (prob) (prob)) {xy. (fst xy * snd xy) mod 5 = 0} = 11 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A fair six-sided die is rolled twice, and the product of the two numbers obtained is taken. What is the probability that the product is divisible by 5? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{11}{36}$.
